And leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Presto be gon, or ile teach you a tricke for your Iackanapes
Learning, they will be deceiued that choose a Tauerne for privacie

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Come our blood cooles; here's to your faire daughter

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Poore girle, I thanke you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: I do not flatter you, but you may be proud, I say no more

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Your daughter, shee's a hansome Gentlewoman, the're be
Worse faces at Court;

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Her complexion is naturall, she has no tricke of art
A litle breeding she has had; and some precepts to guard her Honesty

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Honesty where is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: It should be every where

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Take heed what you say, least you be made to justifie it
Honesty every where?
Heres to you, come.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I speake Bonaldo what I thinke, and it would be no
Dishonour to the greatest to be the first examples.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: If all were of your mind who should thrive in this world?
Pledge me
How shall Christians behave themselves in great offices?
SP.P: Or under-clarkes purchase honesty? but one terme were enough to undoe the City, the Court were but in ill case if great men should stand upon't, for the Countrey, tis bought and sold every market day.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Name it

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: To the Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: The Duke, he does not love me

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: No Bovaldo he does not,

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: He loves your daughter—

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Tis not Princely, Nay I shall dare to tell him so, but
To his health.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Let it come, me thinkes he is a very fine Gentleman,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I begin to be warme already.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: And one that loves a wench as well—

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: As ill thou wodst say?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: As ill as I, let it be so, I were no good subiect to deny it
To his Highnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Thou knewest me a Gentleman

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Are you not so still?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: No I'me a Knight, a Lord I know not what,
I'me lost within a wildernesse of names
But I will be my selfe agen—the tother cup.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Tis welcome, shall we double our files?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: This skirmish will doe well

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Charge me home then.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Now I could talke me thinkes.
I will not prostitute Eubella for
The wealth of his whole Dukedome, ther'es no honor
To a noble conscience, he is the greatest coward.
Dares not be honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Right, if a man dares not be honest he is a Coward
But he that dares be dishonest,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Dares cut his fathers throat

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: A pretty fellow heres to you agen; shalls have a wench? now am I addicted to embrace any thing in the likenesse of a woman, oh for a Chamber-maide to wrestle withall; send for a brace of Basaliskes, thou hast no spirit no Masculine vertue, now could I o're runne the whole Countrey of the Amazons. Heres to a Penthesilia beare up my valiant Mirmidon and we will do such feates shall make the Troians wonder at our backes and bring Dame Hellen to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I prethee leave this humor, tis not generous,

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: How not generous take heed what you say

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I shanot eate my words

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Then drinke your drinke,
Now Troy burnesblew, wheras Hecuba?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Thou art all for wenching,

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: Vpon a condition I will drinke to thee

No, no, thou wot not doe so much, and a man should die for a lift a'the leg: the Duke has a great minde to thy daughter, he is but mortall flesh and bloud, there be subjects that have as sound bodies no dispraise to his Excelency.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Dee not feare to talke thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Feare? would any durst send to me such
A virgin Pinnace, rigd and gay with all flags.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: This is uncivilll, and I shall tell Bonaldo

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: Nay nay, thou art so waspish, if a friend desired a curtesie, that is in fashion; because the Duke—

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Y'are too bold, and forget your selfe, I am
Ashamd of this converse; because the Duke?
Did his hand graspe the Scepters of the world
And would propound e'm all to buy the honor
Of my Eubella, I would scorne his salarie
And tell him he were poorer in his soule
Then he that feedes ith hospitall, I'me armd
And shall grow very angry with your humor
Which ere it nam'd my daughter carried wickednesse
Enough, but in her cause I am easily
Provok'd to teach that tongue repentance dares
Traduce her whitnesse, I allow a mirth
But do not love this madnesse, and if I
Might counsell you, there is a way to quench
These wild licencious flames, earnest of those
Our soules shall feele hereafter, we are both
In yeeres, and should looke out our winding sheet
Not women,

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Boy Ile pay the reckoning; Be honest and see what will
Come on't
Ile seeke out my sonne Hippolito.
Hee'e be ruld by me, here's a coile about a tassell Gentle

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Hee's drunke already
That which has raisd me but to noble anger
Is his distraction, theres for your wine
Now to the wanton Duke, heaven let him see
His shame and know, great men that practise lust
Both kill their body and corrupt their dust,
Let him fret do what he can,
The world shall call, Sebastian honest man. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Had I but one thing that did touch on honor
My friendship, and is that disead already
And languishing? was it for this I would not
See her that I might trespasse with more guilt
When she was married? are not other women
As faire and tempting? or am I hurried
By violence of my fate to love her best
That should be most a stranger? and does she
Meet my modest flame? nay must the tapers
Sacred to Hymen light us to our sinnes?
Lust was too early up in both, oh man
Oh woman! that our fires had kissd like lightning
Which doth no sooner blaze but is extinct, shee's here.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Where's your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.L: There he is Madam

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Why do you walke so melancholy sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: I was collecting my selfe about some businesse
Must be dispach'd this morning, sirra pray
The groome make ready my horse

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Not yet
You do not meane to leave me o'the suddaine?
I am alone, my husband is at Court,
Pray rob me not of all my company,
I shall not thinke upon his absence, with
So much sorrow if you make me happy
With your society.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: There's the Divell already, I cannot leave her
My boy may go howsoever. Exit. Page

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Oh Hippolito
If you have usd no charmes but simple courtship,
Perhaps you may condemne me in your thoughts
That I so soone (not studying the wayes
Of cunning to disguise my love, which other
Women have practis'd, and would well become
The modesty of a wife) declare my selfe
At your dispose, but I suspect you have
Some command more then Naturall, I have heard
There have beene too much witchcraft exercis'd
To make poore women dote

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: You are not serious
In what you say? I hope you do not take me
For such a juggler? if you thinke I practise

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: That looke acquits you, then at my nativity
Some powerfull starre raignd, I have heard Astrologers
Talke much of Venus

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: And of Mars when they are
in coniunction, they encline us mortalls
Strangly to love and ly with one another

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I am ignorant
What influence we have from them, but I
Am sure, something has strangely wrought on me

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: As how Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Why to love, I know not home,
You know my meaning, but truth witnesse with me
When first I saw your person I gave up
My liberty, me thought I lov'd you strangely.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: I had desires too I could not justifie
But knowledge that you were my friends, for that time
All loose fires, but love that swaid you, then quenchd
And kept your thoughts longing, met with my heart
And scald it up for you, yet when I thinke on Bellemente.
Theres wrestlings in my blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Iust when I thinke on him tis so with mine,
That love should be so equall, do'st not stirre you
Sometimes to thinke of former vowes? Nay I do dreame
Sometimes of being surprizd in thy deere armes
And then methinkes I weepe, and sigh and wake.
With my owne grones.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: I never dreame of that

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: It is my foolish fancie, yet such feares
Should waking never trouble me, those lovers
That have not art to hide, and to secure
Their amorous thefts, deserve to be reveald:

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Sure there's no woman in the world but this
Could have such power against my friend, each sillable
Renewes her force upon me,

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I beseech you
Although a storme hath throwne me on your shore
Have not so litle charity to thinke
I should accept of safety on another,
It is not possible any but your selfe
Withall the Magicke of his tongue or fortunes
Could bribe me from Bellemente, if I fall
For too much loving you, your mercy may
Interpret fairely, by these teares

SP.SPEAKER: Gro.
SP.P: Sir your horse is ready

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: I shanot go yet, Lady if you please
Wee'l walke a turneith Garden. Eeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Gro-
SP.L: Harke you my small friend, without offence is not your
Master a —

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.P: What

SP.SPEAKER: Gro.
SP.P: I would have another word for a whooremaster

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: How my durty rubber of horse heeles

SP.SPEAKER: Gro.
SP.P: Nay I do not say he is, I do but aske, whether he be or no, Be not angry demilance, there be as good gentlemen as he, that love a wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Why is your Mistresse a wench?

SP.SPEAKER: Gro.
SP.P: My Mistresse you didapper

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: I do not say she is, I do but aske whether she be or no, there be as hansome creatures none dispraisd, that take mony for their warren, have I answerd you my bold Marchant of dung in a wheele barrow?

SP.SPEAKER: Gro.
SP.P: How now Iackalent is shreeds of Satten, I shall swing you with a horse-rod, you whippet

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Go meddle with your masters Gelding, and cheate him in the provender to keepe you in perpetuall pots of Ale, when you en∣tertaine the Kitchinmaide in the hayloft, talke of my Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Gro.
SP.P: Meddle with my Mistresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Yes Ile speake to her to allow you a lesse proportion of cleane straw to rubb bootes and ly in sirra, you thinke you are at rack and manger, when you devide beanes with the horses and helpe to foule the stable

SP.SPEAKER: Gro.
SP.P: Sirra whelpe that has eaten knot-grasse, do not provoke me least I fetch a smith and curry your thin sids

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Mine you beane-shifter, would you durst no better ride booty at the horse match or cosen your Master ith next parcell of Oates, I feare you not my canvas serving-man with halfe a livery, groome othe stable once removd from the farrier.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.L: What at difference?
Both No not we Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Sirra come hither.
Entreat my father meet me at Court,

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: I shall sir

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Theres no hast for my Nag yet. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: About your businesse sira.

SP.SPEAKER: Gro.
SP.P:
My businesse is below staires, and with a Gelding, what he
may prove I know not well, what I thinke I will keepe to my selfe, my Lady may be honest enough, but he that is borne to be a Cuckold shall never dy a bachelor. Exit.
SP.STAGE: A Song which done. Enter Sebastian and Courtiers.

LG.L: Duke My Lord you are welcome

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Give me leave to tell
Your highnesse I suspect it.
Why should a Prince dissemble?

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: This dialect becomes you not

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Sir sir I must be honest

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Father

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Eubella expresse thy duty
To him thou calst a father, for thy owne
Sake leave this place, the Court's a fire

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: How sir

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Canst thou not see the flames that threaten thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Sebastian's wild

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: But you would make her tame, looke looke Eubella
The Duke himselfe burnes, do not his eyes sparcke
With lust, his very breath will blast thee

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: I feare this will be dangerous, good sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: If yet thou hast not lost thy innocence
I charge thee, by thy mothers memory
And colder ashes, keepe thy selfe unstaind
Let no temptation corrupt a thought
Th'art richer in thy chastity, then all
The Kings of earth can make thee, if thou fall
Thou kilst my heart

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: All this for thy sake we forbeare to punish,
But you should know my Lord

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Lord me no Lords
I grone under the burden of your honors
And here resigne all, give me but my daughter

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Let not your passion strangle thus your reason

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Let not a sinne so blacke as lust degrade
A Prince and register thy dishonord name
With foule adulteries

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Yare very bold

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I would preserve the name of our yet honest famil
I feare she is ore come already, I do not like her silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: To take off your feares
Although we neede not give you satisfaction,
By this white brow, she is as pure as when
She came to Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Oh let Sebstian fall
Lower sir, I beseech you tread upon me
So you will still be honest to my child,
She is all my comfort

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: rise.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: But will you not
Hereafter study to betray her innocence?
Or give her licence to returne with me?
Ile aske no more assurance, grant but this
And when we are at home, it shall oblige us
Beside the duties we already owe
In heart to pray for you

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: We are not pleasd, she should depart.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Then Ile vnthanke your Goodnesse
And dare thus boldy tell your highnesse, lawes
Are most unjust that punish petty theeves
And let the great ones scape,

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: We are yet patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Deere sir

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Princes may take our children from us, not
To aduance but kill their names, corrupt their vertues;
When needy men, that steale to feed their lives
Are doo'md to the Gallouse.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Take the frantick hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Take hence the ravisher

SP.SPEAKER: Cour.
SP.L: Sebastian.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Although he ravish not Eubella
From her selfe, yet he does ravish
A daughter from her father, and ile voice it
Through every streete, I am not bound to whisper
When griefes so loud within me.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Place him where his noise may make his owne headake not others,
This liberty of tongue shall be corrected

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: It will but spread thy infamy, when men
Shall speake my cause, and thy lasciviousnes
Which I will tell so often to the stones
The vault shall be ashamd to eccho thee Eubella

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Away with him

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Do bury me alive, be strong Eubella
And let not death by my example shake thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: This may incline her, do not weepe Eubella
They are not worth a teare, yet tis within
Thy power to ransome their bold heads, were they
Humbled toth block, this Pitty shewes a child
But Princes loose their awe that are too mild.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Where's your Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: In her Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Whoe's with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: None but the Gentleman you left here

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Hippolito? I wonot have so base a thought—Ilt to e'm,
Yet, you may go and say I am returnd and wish her presence.
Ha? there is something busie with my braine Exit. Ser.
And in the shape of jealousie presents
A thousand feares, they have beene very loving
Since we were married; thou soules corrupter
Who sent thee to me? to distract my peace,
Be gon, be gon, and scatter thy foule seedes▪
Vpon a ground that will be fruitfull to thee.
The innocence I carry in my breast
Armes me against the thoughts of others treason,
My friend, my wife? the very names are sacred
And like the heads of Saints, and holy Martyrs
Invested with such glorious beames they strike
Conspiracy blind, how now, whats in thy face? Enter Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Oh sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Whats the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Would you could understand without my tongue

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: How does thy Lady

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: My Lady is—

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Ha▪ why dost pause vilaine? answer me

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Alas I know not with what words to tell you
Would I had never seene her, or you never
Married her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Ha? stay there, Shall I trust thee now fury? but speake, and
Be not tedious, what is my Lady doing upon thy life?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Alas sir it will make you madde.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Speake or never speake agen, I am prepard

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Pardon my unhappinesse to deliver then
A truth that will distract you, you have now
Nor friend nor wife

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Are they both dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Yes dead to honor, finding her chamber lockt
I know not what did prompt me to make use
Of a small cranny, where I beheld em both,
I want modest language
To tell how they are falne, and yet too soone
I know you cannot choose but understand me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: How long hast thou beene a Raven?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Good sir collect your selfe,
Tis my misfortune and no fault to be
The sad reporter

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Do I live still?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: And shall I hope long

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Th'art most uncharitable, if thou hadst lou'd
Thy master thou wouldst wish him happinesse
Which all life denies, is my composition
So hard, a sorrow great and high like this
Cannot disolve it? wonot my heart breake
With this? then melt it some celestiall fire,
In pitty of my sufferings some cloud
Of raine, since my owne eyes refuse to drowne me,
Fall and orewhelme this miserable Iland

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Can this be possible? be sure they are Divells
Or I shall find such a new hell for thee—

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: I would it were not true

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: I would it were not true

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Some mercifull whirlewind snatch this burden up
And carry it into some wildernesse:
Leave not
If it were possible the mention
Of what I was behind, the wolues are honester
Then mankind is to man, I prethee kill me
I kneele to be destroyd, it is thy duty;
When thou shalt tell the world my wretched story
And what soule killing and devouring griefes
Thy good hand rid me of, it shall acquit thee
And call thy murder charity

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Good sir

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: O whither shall I runne to find a friend
Will do the gentle office to despatch me
Without my owne hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Rather live to take
Iustice upon their periuries.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Good man.
My better Angel how had I forgot
My selfe? Coward to thinke of dying yet.
Who would put confidence in heaven hereafter.
If it should suffer me depart the world
Without revenge, and that my owne upon em.
Come draw, take my sword, I will be double arm'd▪
I charge thee by duty, or thy life
If that be more, stay you at bottome of
The staires, while I ascend their sinfull chamber
And if my Pistoll misse his treacherous heart
He has no way to passe but on thy sword,
The place gives such advantage that with
Safety thou maist command his life.
Kill him with losse compunction then a witch
Fleas a dead Infant for his skin to perfect
A hellish incantation, thou wo't do't?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Ile do my best he scape

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Wife, friend,
You hang like vlcers on me, I am bound
To cut you from my heart to cure my wound.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Quartus.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Hippolito and Clariana upon a bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: WHat pitty tis these pleasures are not lawfull.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Lawfull? that would take much from the delight
And value, I have heard some Gentlemen,
That want no venison of their owne,
Sweare they had rather strike their neighbors deere
Then hunt in their owne parke, what we possesse
We keepe for our necessity, not game,
Or wearied with enjoying give't a way
To purchase thanks abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.P: For all that Madam, there is danger in some purlies, and when the Keeper is none of the wisest, their bolts are sooner shot, I like the sport, but would not be taken at the deere stealing, yet for such a Doe as thou art, I would venter—

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Tis no glory to take a towne without some hazard, that victorie is sweetest which is got in the face of danger, when the very cannons are hoarse with clamor, then the bold souldier goes on and thinkes the noise loude musicke to him, give me the man that feares no colours, was there ever any thing worth the enioy∣ing that came easily and without trouble to us? what makes a maidenhead the richer purchase thinke you? but I am married and my husband is your friend

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Prethee no more o'that

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P:
No more othat, in my conscience you are fearefull this is the ballad right. Courtier hey Courtier ho, wilt thou be my true love, no no no, fy upon't. I should name my husband often to arme and fortifie our selves▪ I confesse, I do not wish him here, perhaps he would do some mischiefe, and hinder another meeting, but if he were present now, and should see us kisse, for and he' were ten husbands, I would trust his eyes no further, what
could he say? for he did but kisse her, for he did but kisse her, and so let her go: come for shame be more sprightly, I have as much reason to looke about, and play my game wisely, if my Cards were considerd.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.P: Yet you are very confident.

SP.SPEAKER: Cl.
SP.P: He does use to keep his word, I know heele not returne this two houres, come we are secure, prethee lets talke o something els.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Of death.
Are ye vntwind?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Are we betraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: You did not looke for me—your sword is of no use, dee see Pitty your owne damnations; and obey me, get into that closet no considering, it must be done: so you are fast, now Lady Lechery dresse you the bed a litle, and lay the pillowes hansomely bestirre you

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Vpon my knees—

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: No petitioning, you can sing, quickly or—so so, you sirra at the bottome of the staires, come up. Be wise and do not kneele nor whimper. Enter Servant.

LG.L: Now sirra speake and tell me truly
Or ile search every corner of thy soule
Why didst thou play the vilaine, thus to mocke me
With expectation to find my wife

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Hold sir I beseech you

SP.SPEAKER: Bël.
SP.L: What Divell did instruct thee to disquiet
My heart, secure and confident of their honors
As conscious of my owne, no head but mine
To bruise with jealosie, where is he? shew me
Or take into thy bosome what my vowes
Had fixt for him and her

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: If these be eyes I saw em'

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: If these be eyes, is that your proofe, lay such
A cause upon the strength of a weake sence
That is a thousand wayes deceiv'd, your eyes!
O Clariana, this impudent slave
With such a cunning face, told me thou wert
Naught, lock'd in the lustfull armes of base
Hippolito, my friend, my honest friend.
One that commands not his owne life so much
As I, that wo'd not for a Monarchy
Do me the least disgrace, hast found him vilaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Ile looke under the bed sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: And I beleevd him too, and had I found
But the least point of such a sinne, within
Thy Chamber, furies should appeare more tame
then Bellamente, hell should not have malice.
Enough to adde to my revenge, but pardon.
My easie credulous nature, I confesse
A fault, for had I lov'd thee nobly as
Became our holy vowes, our vowes Clariana
To which we cald the Angells, I should never
Have entertained one thought against thy chastity
But this slave shall repent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Hold, I beseech you sir? by my life I thought
I saw em.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thought? is that excuse

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Good sir, Ile never trust my owne eyes after this
There was deceptio visus. Oh be mercifull

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: None but her honor, and my friends to poison?
Had this report not first arrived at me
How had we all beene shamd—dost thou kneele too
Nay then I must forgive him, rise my honest
My deerest Clariana—but I shall heare
You will be prating of it, if one sillable
Come to my eare let fall by thee, that touches
But thy suspition, Ile ha thy tongue
And heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Cut me into a thousand peeces. Madam your pardon
How was I cosend

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Be gon and thanke her goodnesse thou dost live
But do not dare to be so desperate
To come within my eye reach till I call thee

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Ile not come neere you, Ile bury my selfe in the Cellar. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: So so▪ Now sir you may come forth agen
Nor do you my most excellent whoore, thinke
There is no storme to follow—keepe your distance
You have had a feast, a merry one, the shot
Is now to be discharg'd, what do you expect?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Death, from that hand, I apprehend no mercie
Not have I so much innocenee to hope
You will delay your justice,, were I arm'd
With power to resist, I should adde more
Offences by defending of this life
That has so basely iniured you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Treacherous serpent

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: With this I have sometime releeud your valour
And had no pitty of my blood, but then
I was a friend, in such a cause as this
I have no arme no weapon, not, if I
Were sure the bullet would dceline my heart.
It does beget a cowardise to thinke
How I am falne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: O pardon

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Pardon with what conscience canst thou aske it?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You shewed a charity above my hope
By giving a few minutes for my prayer,
Which shewes you had no meaning to destroy
The soule, twas Rare compassion, but if you
Could possibly forgive?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: How forgive

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I say if it were possible you could
Remitt so foule (in me the blakst) offence
Not for the love I have to number dayes
But by some noble service, to wash off
This shame, this leprosie upon my name

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Ha you found it now.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I have but vainely interrupt your fury
You cannot must not pardon it, such mercie
Becomes not an Italian.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Miserable woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: O sir, it was my first offence, what woman is
Without some staine? if all that in this kind
Have sinn'd, had met with present death you would
Not find some names, that now shine gloriously
Within the catalogue of Saints, my soule
Is full of shame and teares.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Tel me Clariana▪
Still I shall hit upon thy name, how couldst thou
Vse me so cruelly? did I want youth
And spring about me were my embraces cold
Frost in my blood? or in thy bed was I
Conueyd a snowball, rould up the children
Do to play with winter, did I not affect thee
Beyond all the comfort of the world?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: And thou whom best of all mankind I lov'd
Whose friendship tooke up my whole heart till she
Came in a wife, yet then thou hadst a seate
One small degree below her, when this shall be
The talke of Ferrara who shall trust his friend
For thy sake, or at the mention of thy name
For sweare ever to marry

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Noble sir.
It is within your power

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: To kill you both

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I am prepared so well
As this short time will give me leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Tis yet within your power to silence all,
What is already done should we turne fountaines
We heartily may grieve for, not repaire,
The world can have no knowledge of our trespasse
Nor your dishonor, If you call it so
Vnlesse you tell it, you have nobly sir
Secur'd all shame at home, which has won more
Repentance from me then my teares, go on
Increase that piety, and be not you
The trumpet of their infamy abroad
Whose lives hereafter may be spent with such
Religious sorrow for offending you
That you may not repent to have forgiven.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Shall I be wonne with foolish pitty?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Our death will gaine you nothing, but the feare
You shannot keepe your owne life

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Or if bloud
Must onely satisfie, let your sword here
Bath in revenge, the greatest sinner kill
If men were not, what woman could be ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Your feares thus vanish, I delight not in
The bloody sacrifie, live both.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: A miracle

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: But ile do more then kill you—tak my love off.
I do desire never to see you more,
Nor will I be a Courtier to occasion
Meeting hereafter, what is done is circled
Within our knowledge, pray, farwell, for you
I do desire never to bed thee more
Ile force some smiles to keepe suspition off
But feare I never shall love heartily
Agen, thou hast undone me here, Clariana
And yet I wonot wish thee dead for this
Repent and when I die aske for a kisse. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Bon.
SP.P: Not at the Court? why he desired I should meet him here

SP.SPEAKER: Cour.
SP.P: The Duke hath often asked for him

SP.SPEAKER: Bon.
SP.P: He waites well in the meane time, who in the name of wantonnesse keepes him away, I know tis a wench, tis a parlous boy, my owne sonne to a haire, and he should not love a woman I would disinherit him, for I am of opinion an Athist sometime is better then an Eunnch, And yet cannot the Court find him game enough, but he must leape the pale and straggle so farre for Venison, that the Duke must hunt after him; and he were not my owne flesh and bloud, I would counsell him to marry, but they are dangerous, and a disease is more curable then a wife, for she indeed is a hetick feauer although I buried mine seven yeere agoe, yet I feele a grudging of her still, and for a need could guesse at the change of weather by the knowledge her noise has infud into my bones.

SP.SPEAKER: Cour.
SP.P: The Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: Some one looke out Hippolito

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: If please your grace let it be my imployment

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: Your highnesse humble servant▪ I am sorry my sonne should be absent, when your grace has service for him, but Ile find him out, I am acquainted with two or three of his haunts I know a Taverne is next doore to a—

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: To a what?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: It has a course name

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: No matter:

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: To a baudyhouse

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: Thats not impossible

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: To find him there, I cannot helpe it?

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: He loves him the better for't

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: Tis a tricke he learnd in France sir, where your nobility practise, he will leave it, when Capring and Kissing are out of fashion with Gentlemen

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: Oh he is young, I have heard you were as wild at his Yeeres,

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: And wilder too I should be sorry else

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: I had ne're broke my wives heart else, with supping abroad and midnight revells▪ I should ha beene troubled with her till this time

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: She was a shrew it seemes? but you promise actively still?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Not much for the crosse point,
But with your highnesse licence, Ile find out Hippolito
To attend your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Good Signior Exit.
A blunt honest Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: He does not boast much honesty, with your pardon sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: I like the freedome of his discourse, but see Hippolito

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I must not appeare melancholy

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Signior the Duke expects you

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: His graces humble creature

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Now is he come from some vaulting schoole Ile lay my life,
He is a pretty Gentleman tis pitty that nothing can perswade him from the flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. C.
SP.L: The Duke imployes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: I leiger at home

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Both in prison

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Both.
We all know Eubella, her father is committed to prison for being
To free on's tongne.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Be confident I will prevaile, I have a new spell for her

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Be speedy and be fortunate, she is in that chamber
Returne with her consent to love and be
What the Dukes power can make thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You too much honor me

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Come Gentleman.

DIV2.STAGE: Hippo. seemes to open a chamber doore and brings forth Eubel.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: Lady, I am sent to know your full and finall resolution touching the businesse the Duke propounded, though your father be shut up yet change of aire is fitter for your complexion, the Duke is a Gentleman that may command in these parts tis not for want of provision, the Duke has a mind to cut up your virginity.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: If this be your affaire sir, tell the Duke
Eubella is a rocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Thats very hard

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: His mermaids cannot winne me with their songs
Nor all his tempests shake me

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Stay a litle
There's something more in my commission

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Hippolito
I now have argument to thinke you were
Not borne a Gentleman, something, here is witnesse
I pittie thee, this is no noble office

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You meane a pander it ha's been a thriving way for some,
But I am imployed by his grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Shall feare or flattery
Corrupt a generous soule? I am a woman
The weakest of a thousand yet I dare
Give man example, rather to be sacrificed.
Then betray vertues cause, we give our life
To grow agen, from our owne funerall pile
Like the Assyrian brid.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip
SP.L: Thou hast so rich
A stocke of goodnesse, were all other women
Vitious, thou mightst impart enough to make
The whole sexe white agen, and leave thy selfe
One degree lesse then angell: canst thou pardon
That I have tempted thee so farre? thy hand
To give it a relligious kisse, when next
My tongue is orator in so foule a cause
The argument it selfe turne a disease
And eate it to the roote. I am chang'd Eubella
And more to trie thy strength then to orecome
I speake nowe for the Duke, keepe still thy thoughts
Deuout to honor, after I have studied
A yeares repentance for my wrongs to thee,
I will presume to say I love Eubella

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: But hath Hippolito no other meaning?
I understand, and take some ioy to heare this language

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: The first proofe of my conversion
Shall be to tell the Duke he has done ill
To court thee sinfully Enter Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Howes this?

SP.SPEAKER: b Eu.
SP.L: Pray do not mocke, if you knew how much,
Delight heaven takes to heare you speake so well
To the distressed Eubella.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: By this lip
If my profane touch make thee not offended
There is no good I will not act, nor ill
I will not suffer to deserue thy love
But I am miserable and cannot merit
I have not beene at home these many yeeres
Yet I will call my conscience to account
For all, and throw my selfe upon heavens charity,
Why dost thou weepe?

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: My ioy can weare no other livery
Then teares, and confident all this is truth
I cannot keepe it in, you shall dispose
Eubellas heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Then here I take it in
To my possession

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Vilaine Strumpet

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Sir, here are none such I can assure your highnesse

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Is this your faith to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: I never did you.
True service till this minute, and I dare
Now tell you, though you cut my head off, tis
Not justice to pursue the ruine of
A harmelesse maid

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Traytor

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Call me some Name, I understand my Lord
This virgin now is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Your whoore

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: This cannot make me yet forget your person

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Sir I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: By my Dukedome

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: The more you vex the more we grow together
In honor and chast love

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: You speake as if
You were to be her husband,

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Tis a title a prince should be ambitious of.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Very fine
Do you consent too, to be cald his wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: If he dare make me such there is no second
My heart affects.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Ist come to this? then heare what I determine

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Sir consider

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: I have considered do not interrupt me
Too morrow if I live Ile see you both
Married, thou excellent maide forgive my passion,
Accept him freely, thou hast overcome
With chastity, and taught me to be a prince
Which character, my lust had neere defac'd
Release Sebastian.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: What dutie can poore Eubella pay?

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: No more, good deeds reward themselves, how have we slept.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: This exceeds all your favours▪

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: Cherish my gift Hippolito, she is a wife for the best prince, no honor can be enough to satisfie thy vertue. Exit,

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Heres a strange whirle, I do not like it, if the Duke con∣tinue this mind, we must all be honest.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Co.
SP.L: Who can helpe it?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Bellamente and Bonaldo at severall doores.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Save you Signior is my sonne here?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: He wa's here very lately, too late

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: You do not answer as you were wont,
I aske for Hippolito, your friend,

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: And did not I answer you?
Cry you mercie Signior, indeed he is not here

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: How is it with your beauteous Clariana?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Shee's well

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Pray commend my service to her

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What said yee?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Nothing but my service to your Lady

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Oh I thanke you, pray stay, and tell me how I looke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Looke?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: They will perswade me within I am not well
I must confesse there is some cause of melancholy
Within me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: I guest so at first sight, may I presume to aske it?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: And yet does not concerne me in a higher nature then
My friend, a scuruy chance late hapn'ed to him
One that he lov'd most deerely, you will scarce
Beleeve, made him a Cuckold

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: That all?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: That all. Dee understand what I have said?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Yes a friend was made a Cuckold by a friend
He did his wife and him a curtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Go home and pray, y'are in a desperate state
This is enough to weigh thee downe to hell

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: I am not of your mind, and I had don't my selfe, I should
Never had so much despaire as to hang my selfe, why tis as
Common as shifting a trencher

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: But harke you sir, how ere you talkeou cannot in your judgement thinke so, are you married?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: What dee see in my forehead you should thinke me so miserable?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Ile tell you then, what a wife is, or should be

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: I can tell you, what they should be,

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: They should be honest and love their husbands, and for their Sakes their bastards, which if they understand they are bound, to keepe, because their ill conditions drive us a broad to get 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: No, heare me.
A wife is mans best peece, who till he marries
Wants making up, she is the shrine to which
Nature doth send us forth on Pilgrimage,
She was a syens taken from that tree
Into which if she have no second grafting
The world can have no fruit, she is mans
Arithemeticke which teaches him to number
And multiply himselfe in his owne children,
She is the good mans Paradise, and the bads
First step to heaven, a treasure which who wants
Cannot be trusted to posterity
Nor pay his owne debts, she is a golden sentence
Writ by our maker, which the Angells may
Discourse of, only men know how to use
And none but devills violate

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: All this youle justifie a wife

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Now tell me Signior what punishment
That man deserves, that should deface or steale
This wealth away.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: How meane you in the way of lying with her?
I am of my first opinion, there is not much treason
In't, if she be hansome

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: But is there no respect of friendship to be observ'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Nor kindred much in such a case

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Would you not chide your sonne that should abuse his
Deere friends wife or Mistresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.P: Yes if he should abuse her, but if he did but ly with her I should commend him, make the case your owne would you deny a friend that wanted linnen the curtesie of your cleane shirt? a wo∣man is a more necessary wearing, and yet never the worse for't

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Away thou wot infect my dwelling else,
To what a monster, is man growne

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Fare you well sir, I ha but answered to your questions

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Cynick Ile hold thy Lanthorne now, and goe with thee
Through Athens and the world to find one man
That's honest. Enter Page.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: My Master remembers his humble service

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: To me? Ide rather thanke him to forget it
Why does he trouble me with letters? yet Ile read em.
Ha? to be married to morrow—This is an honest
Sentence, my heart bleeds still for wronging you.
Clariana Tis no secret

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Ha to Eubella, I shanot conceale my passion, he must not marry

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Give me the paper

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Inspire me love ile crosse it Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Why does thy master boy, send me this letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: I know not sir; unlesse it be to certifie you of his marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: He will marry now and live honest, heaven give him joy.
But its not so faire to disturbe my braine
That is not fully setled with his triumphes,
What ist to me? He cannot satisfie.
My jniurie if he should court his wife
And prevaile with her
To imbrace me too.
The Duke he writes, will honor his solemnity
His conscience dares not suffer him to invite
Me as his guest, why then must I be troubled
Cannot he laugh and hm and kisse his bride
But he must send me word, whose soule he has
Put miserably out of tune. Enter Clariana.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Conceale that letter from all eyes but your Masters.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Sirra you shall returne, and say I will dy shortly.

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.L: Heaven forbid sir

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: That is a kind of prayer, who bad thee thee sayo?
Then if I must live, Ile find out a Hermit
That dwells within the earth or hollow tree.
A great way hence there I shall be secure
And learne to pray for I want charity—be gon boy

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Good sir talke not so strangely

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Fare you well too, Ile come agen to morrow, or I know
Not when, I have much businesse abroad

SP.SPEAKER: Cla,
SP.L: Will you ride forth?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes,

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Shall none attend you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: No I shall be best alone, you know your chamber
Theres none so bold to rob me of my griefe
Yet he thats sad as I; beares his owne thiefe.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Quintus.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.P: I Know not what to resolue, this letter has distracted me It is not wisedome to acquaint Eubella, let me perus't agen. Sir, though I have repented my love, which drew my dishonor, I have not lost my charitie, and therefore can take no pleasure in your ruine, meet me to morrow earely in the groue behind the Pallace, I will discover a plot against your life, I pitty your danger, and will secure more ioyes to your bride, be secret yet and trust her, that is no otherwise then nobly yours, Clariana.

LG.L: Tis some thing Bellamente has designd.
For his revenge, did he speake strangely saist?

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.P: Very strangely sir, he said he would dy shortly

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.P:
Thou didst mistake him, he meant I should dy, he wonot ill me at the altar? perhaps I shall be poisoned at dinner, a thousand wayes there are to let out life
I must be certaine. Eubella and her father
Enter Eubella and Sebastian.
Some truce with my affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: More welcome then my liberty, Eubella
Has made my heart glad with your new character
And now my sonne Hippolito.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: That title
Will be aboue all honors the Duke can
Let fall upon me, that I have beene wild
I must with shame remember, but my study
Of after life to her and all the world
I hope shall purchase thee a better name.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: You will not leave us this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I shall returne, excuse me a few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Do what you please▪ but if it be a businesse
You may dispence with

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: It concernes my honor, but nothing shall
Detaine me long; all places are but darkenesse
Without thy eies, Ile visit em' agen

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: How soone?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: You shall scarce thinke me absent

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: We must expect you then.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: May the day shine bright upon thee

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: And all the blessings of it waite on you

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Signior you are most welcome, I entreat you
To call my girle your daughter

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: My sonne has made this choise I heare, Ile
Call her any thing

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: I shall expresse my duty sir, in all things

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: But wheres Hippolito—a buxome thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Sir please you retire, he is new departed

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Whither? a musical lip.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Nay we did not examine his affaire
But we expect his quicke returne

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Wilt please you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: I should be pleasd with such another,—a light wench
And a yare, Ile attend you Lady. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cal.
SP.L: Be just Milena to me, and endeere
My love for ever

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Madam you know my faith

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I promist to meet
Hippolito this morning in the groue
Behind the Pallace, to conferre about
Some businesse that concernes, thou shat presently
Excuse my travell and intreate him hither,
He and my husband lately had some difference
I know not why, in this convenient absence
Of Bellamente he securely may
Speake with me here, yet Ile not willingly
Have him come hither by the publick way,
The Garden doore shall be left open for him
And a cleare passage to this Chamber

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Madam I understand,

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Prevaile with him to come, tell him all's safe

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Ile sweare it Madam to do you service

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: But use all hast.
Which way shall I beginne, I shall want art
I feare to winne upon him, oh for some
High, and prevailing oratory to
Expresse what my heart labours with I could
Accuse my unkind desteny, declame
Against the power of love, raile at the charmes
Of language and proportion, that betray us
To hasty sorrow, and too late repentance,
But breath is this way lost, wounds that are made
Require a balsome, and not empty curses
To state our body, should the Marriner
When a storme meetes him, throw away his Card
Neglect himselfe and vessell; and ly downe
Cursing the winds and tempest? If he come
As but to doubt doth make me miserable
The genius of love assist my passion,
I must deliver something that doth make
My poore heart swell, and will if I conceale it
Like fire lockd up in a thick cloud destroy
The prison that containes: shee's returnd
Already. Enter Milena.
What sayes Hippolito?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Like an honest Gentleman, hee's at the graden gate.
I told him how things were at home, I met him
hard by, as if he meant without inviting
Having expected you so long, to come
Neerer, and waite some opportunitie
To speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Th'art fortunate admit him, tis nor
Safe to expect there, but while we conferre
Vse thy best diligence round about to bring
If there be such misfortune, the first newes
Of Bellamente

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Ile be carefull Madam. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I m'e glad hees come
With what looke shall I first salute him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Pray excuse me sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Twill purchase but a paire of Gloves

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I have him at my fingers ends, well I can but thinke
What serviceable creatures we Chambermaids are
Sometimes we are the best Cabinets for Ladies, and they
Trust their Iewells of honor with us, but I must looke
About me, I know my office. Exit,

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Y'aue seene this face before, does it seeme strange?

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: I have seene it, when it was lesse sad, but tis
The richer Iewell set in blacke, you never
Wore garments did so well become you Lady

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I shall not love em'worse because they please
Your Eye, they fit the habit of my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Your voice has better musicke too, it sounds
As some religious melancholy strooke.
Vpon your heart y'aue praid lately I distinguish
A teare upon your cheeke still tis well done

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: If there be any signe of sorrow here
Tis for your sake

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: I cannot blame thy eyes,
If every time, I ame presented to 'em
Th' unhadpy obiect thou dost weepe Clariana,
I have deserved to find the lowest place
Within thy charity, yet such is thy
Compassion, when my fate is cast
And my unworthy life markd for the sacrifice
Thou art willing to preserve Hippolito
And to that purpose sentst to speake with me

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: You read my letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Clariana, I
Shall not have time enough to thanke thee, when
Thou hast discovered what conspiracy
Threatens my head, unlesse you use some brevity
There is a worke this morning to be finished
Requires my personall attendance.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I am.
Not ignorant what busnesse is designd
It was the reason of my zealous wishes
To change some words before

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: I waite your purpose

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: You are this morning to receive a wife

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: And such blessing as the earth were poore
Without her,

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Tis Eubella I understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: That most vertuous faire one

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Ile not take from her
I have heard her much commended, but she is
No miracle

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: How Clariana.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Our sex were poore
If she alone had all the grace of woman.
Though she be faire, the Dukedome is not so
Barren but it may shew some parralell.
And let it not be thought a pride, if I
Affirme there have beene those, have said as much
Of me, all beavty is not circumscribd
In one.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: You point at that which takes the Eye
And is but halfe a hansomnesse at best
Vnlesse the mind be furnished with those vertues
Which write a woman faire, but Clariana
There is no time for this dispute, and I
Am somewhat sorry you have falne upont
When I but praisd Eubella modestly,
She is to me the best and fairest now
Of all the world, but turne to the occasion
That brought me hither, I would heare what practise
Is meant against my life, which I would now
Preserue for that deere virgin, more then love
To keepe it for my use, I did imagine
How ever Bellamente shewed a formall
And calme release, yet he would meditate
Revenge at such a time he most should wound me
And had not I a perfect confidence
Your thoughts meant simple pitty to my danger
I should not thus farre have engaged my self,
Then I beseech you tell me

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Why dee delay me thus Clariana?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Pardon o pardon me Hippolito
Indeed I will discover all the plot

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: I am prepard,

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: But there is no misfortune
Leveld at you, the danger is all mine
And I but use this policy, to take
My last farewell, for I must never see
You married

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: You amaze me, what unhappinesse?
Will Bellamente be so cruell to thee
Having forgiven

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: A hand more severe.
Is armd against me

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Is there no prevention

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: It is within your mercy to do much

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.P: Pronounce then as much safety as my strength can give thee against any enemy be
SP.L: But Bellamente, I have wounded him
Too much already, may I credit then
There is treachery ayming at my blood
Declare what man I must oppose in thy
Protection

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: No man

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Y'are misticall

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: A woman is my enemy

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: There will be
No use of valour then

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: But much of love
If you resolve to save bleeding Clariana
Thou must oppose Eubella.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: What was that?
Kill my Eubella?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: It stretches not so farre, onely I beg
You would not marry her, and I shall live.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Not marry her, why theres no steele can bring
So certaine and so violent a death,
Forsake Eubella now, now when shee's drest
My glorious bride, the Nuptiall ceremonie
And Priest expecting us, I know you speake not
In hope I should beleeve, you may as well
Bid me'commit a murder on my life
For this will kill her and we both are one.
Who hath instructed you to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: My love
My love that will not suffer me to know
Thou must be given thus away for ever
I could endure thy absence for whole yeeres
And not complaine, repent my equall sorrow
We have so farre offended, while you keepe
Your present freedome, there were then some hope
A possiblility, at last to meet
In new affections to redeeme the old
But thus my expectation is destroyd,
You understand?

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Too much, be not deceived,
There is no love that is not vertuous
And thy consenting thus farre but in thought
Is sacriledge, and thou dost rob the Church
Twice, first in violation of thy vowes
Which there were registred, and then mine expected
I dare not heare you talke thus

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Is this all?
All the reward for loosing of my selfe
For thy sake?

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Y'are not yet quite lost

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: What curse
Made blacke the houre of my conception
Farewell Hippolito, when you heare me dead
Come to my grave, and drop one teare upon me

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: What meanes Clariana? Enter Milena.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Oh Madam looke behind me
I see my Master comming in, and he
Suspecting my hast this way, followes me
With his sword drawne Enter Bellamente▪

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Are you so nimble? ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Woman thou hast undone me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Oh my fortune againe betraid

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Nay then, Ile make sure worke Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Alas what shall become of me, the doores are lockt.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: Cruell dessembler.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Hippolito the sequell shall acquit
My thoughts, Ime circled with more certaine danger
And cannot hope life

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Tis not that I feare
To dy, thou knowst I am not guilty
Of any second shame, but my Eubella
That every minute lookes to be my bride
How the thought rends me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I can prevent his furie
Against thee

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: There is no way

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Yes this.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi▪
SP.L: Ha divell what hast done?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Alas what ha you both done?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I thanke thee
Thou hast spar'd my execution on my selfe
Ile tell thee now Hippolito, by this
This crimson in whose ebbe my life hasts from me
I did not looke for Bellamente, but
Surprisd I thought it honor to beg in
The tragedy, I know my fate was not
To be resisted, twas impossible.
To find a second mercy from him, and
I would secure no woman after me
Should boast the Conquest of Hippolito
Thy sword was gentle to me, search't againe
And thou shalt see.
How my embracing blood will keepe it warme
And kisse the kind destroyer

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Bellamente and Servants, Milena runns in.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What are you humbled? must not serve your turne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: We have deceivd your triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Bellamente.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Heare me first, and know this bold hand sa'd
Thy fury to Hippolito, whom with
My last breath I pronounce not in a thought
Guilty of new dishonor

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: As soone perswade
It is not day

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: This letter summond me

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: I had no other meanes to speake with him
And my unruly love did prompt me to it

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: I tremble not in my innocence to thinke
Of death but my Eubella, poore Eubella

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: If she but lovd thee as I did, sheel'le follow
Furies will lend a torch to light her to
The shades we go to

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Is the wickednesse all thine?

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Except the wound my hasty sword
Gave as reward for this too neere my heart
I feare

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Dost feare?

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: For poore Eubellas sake

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Now thou hast met a justice in thy blood
For thy first sinne, but I will have a Surgeon

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Send for Eubella rather
Oh let me breath my last upon her lips
It will concerne thee Bellamente somewhat
The world will think this murder was thine else

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Make hast:
O woman thou didst weepe once, when thy teares
Won my forgivenesse, where are all the drops,
The penitent showers, in which thy stained soule
Should bath it selfe, this minute lanching forth
To thy eternity.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.L: Th'are of another colour, oh forgive me
Good heaven, I have wrongd thee Bellamente
Oh wives hereafter, meane your hearts to them
You give your holy vowes, what mist weighs downe
My eyes already, oh tis death I see
In a long robe of darkenesse is preparing
To seale them up for ever, twere no death,
If we could loose our sinnes as we do breath

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Shees gone to a long silence, place her body
There and then gently raise Hippolito
To the other chaire

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Hast, hast my deare Eubella. Enter Bonaldo

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: How came this tragedy?

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: Give me your last blessing
Ime going a long Pilgrimage, you gave
Too great a licence to my youth

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Howes this?

SP.SPEAKER: Hi.
SP.L: My wanton bloud now payes fort, Clariana
And I have changd a wound, where is Eubella?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: She is too neere this griefe, this punishment
Should ha beene mine long since, I was his father
In sinne as well as yeeres, she is dead already
Thy glasse had many sands till it was broken
Then those few minutes that are left of mine,
Ile number with my prayers. Enter Duke. Eub. Seb. Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Hippolito.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.L: My wound hath had a happy patience. Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Eubella

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: He is departed

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Bellamente who hath done all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Ile do my best to tell you
Here's all thats left of them whom how I lov'd,
Heaven and my poore heart knowes,

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: And is he slaine?
But once more let me kisse him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I did not kill em sir, they were too willing
To leave the world together, but their wrongs
All all the paiment for my honest love
awakd me to revenge, and had they beene
The very strings that tye my life together
It should ha falne to peeces, but their hands
Prevented mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: The cause? you rather leade me
To thinke you were their murderer, we must
Be better satisfied or your blood must answer
For this effusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: The cause my Lord—tis growne since it came hither
Pray give me leave, because you shanot suffer
Ith expectation, you shall have it all
Together, this Hippolito and that Clariana
Harke there tis. Enter Milena.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: His griefe has overchargd him

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: None to decipher these sad characters?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: With your pardon I can

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Be comforted Eubella, all thy teares
Will not recall his life

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Pray give me leave
Since he is dead to embalme him, had I di'ed
Before him, hee'd ha wept as much for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: We have heard too much but moderate Eubella,
Thy sorrows, he surviues that will supply
A bridegroome, and thy vertue bids me tender
My selfe a recompence for thy sufferings

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: I know you wod not lead me to forget
Hippolito so soone, I dare not thinke
Of being a Bride agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Does your grace meane this honor?

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: By my Duke dome.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: After this shower is over, she will shine
Doubt not my Lord, and blesse her happy starres

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.L: Lead from this charvell house they shall be interrd
With all solemnity becomes there birth
And when their funerall rites and teares are done
New joyes shall rise with the next mornings Sunne.
